# Asynchronism

  • Callback
    • Callback Example
  • Promises
    • Creation
    • Handling Results
    • Chaining Promises
  • Async/Await
    • Syntax
    • Example
    • Error Handling

# Callback

A callback function is a function passed into another function as an argument.

# Callback Example

fetchBlogs(
    (res)=>{
        setBlogs(res);
    }
);

const fetchBlogs = async (cb) => {
    fetch("http://localhost:8000/api/blogs", {
        method: "GET",
        headers: {
            "Content-Type": "application/json",
        },
    }).then(res => {
        cb(res);
    })
}

# Promises

Object representing the eventual completion (or failure) of an asynchronous operation and its resulting value.

# Creation

const asyncFunction = () =>{
   return new Promise((resolve, reject)=>{
       if([successful condition]){
           resolve()
       } else{
           reject()
       }
   })
}

# Handling Results

A method to attach callbacks to the Promise to be called when their status is changed.

# .then()

Handles when Promise is fulfilled.

myPromise.then((value) => {console.log('Promise fulfilled with value: ', value); });

# .catch()

Handles when Promise is rejected.

myPromise.catch((reason) => {console.log('Promise rejected with reason: ', reason); });

# .finally()

Handles when Promise is settled, regardless of the outcome.

myPromise.finally(() => {console.log('Promise settled'); });

# Chaining Promises

Promises can be chained with the .then() method. With error handling.

fetchBlogs().then((res) => {
    console.log(res);
}).catch(err => {
    console.log(err);
});

const fetchBlogs = async () => {
    fetch("http://localhost:8000/api/blogs", {
        method: "GET",
        headers: {
            "Content-Type": "application/json",
        },
    }).then(res => {
        resolve(res);
    }).catch(err => {
        reject(err);
    });
}

# Async/Await

# Syntax

Either using the function keyword or arrow function.

# Function

async function myFunction() {
    const response = await fetch(/* ENDPOINT */);
    const responseData = await response.json();
    return responseData;
}

# Arrow Function

const myFunction = async () => {
    const response = await fetch(/* ENDPOINT */);
    const responseData = await response.json();
    return responseData;
}

# Example

async function fetchData() {
    try {
        const response = await fetch('https://api.example.com/data');
        const data = await response.json();
        console.log('Fetched data: ', data);
    } catch (error) {
        console.log('Error fetching data', error);
    }
 }

# Error Handling

# try...catch()

async function myFunction() {
    try { 
        //Code block
    } catch(error) {
        console.log(error);
    }
}

# then...catch()

myPromise
    .then((response) => {
        throw new Error(`Error`);
    )}
    .catch((error) => {
        console.error(${error});
    });
